Silver Lake Partners may bid $15 per share for Dell

Message.Title: HEAVY HEAVY VOLUME
Message.Msg: fast and furious

Message.Title: NEWS PLAN B
Message.Msg: By Nadia Damouni and Greg Roumeliotis NEW YORK (Reuters) - A bid to take Dell Inc private by buyout firm Silver Lake and its partners underscores the financing market's willingness to lend up to $15 billion to the world's No.3 PC maker -- money that could be used to buy back shares and pay dividends even if the deal doesn't come together. The Silver Lake-led bidding group has lined up debt financing from at least four major banks and is negotiating a final price to pay Dell shareholders, people familiar with the matter have said. Should the buyout talks collapse, Dell could still choose to borrow itself and embark on a large share repurchase, in what investors and analysts refer to as a "Plan B". "Whatever they are going to do, they could do in a public setting," said a senior executive at a competing private equity firm that is not currently involved in the deal. "Shareholders could demand that Dell borrows the same money Silver Lake was going to borrow, buy back shares from whomever wants to sell them, and whoever stays involved can go about restructuring the business. That's a possible outcome here," the executive said on condition of anonymity. This "Plan B" could also be deployed in the event that Dell shareholders reject any buyout deal reached between Silver Lake and Dell, shareholders and analysts said. This could be one viable alternative to a sale, and could increase Dell's negotiating power as it tries to agree on a final price with Silver Lake, they added.

Message.Title: Last Push: No Deal for Dell
Message.Msg: I’ve been bullish on this LBO before, but now it seems that this deal is just too big to consummate. On the one hand, SL will offer up to $15.00/share, but on the other side, major shareholders want around $18.00/share. It has been over three weeks now since the report came out about the LBO. The latest offer from SL just maybe its last. Having said that, I am very pessimistic on this deal; sell your shares before the pullback.

Message.Title: Silver Lake Just Established $15 per share as new floor
Message.Msg: and, according to charlie gasparino (tweet about six hours ago), banks indicating deal imminent.... market needs overnight to digest fairly credible rumors and tomorrow a more significant pop

My guess is $12.50 per share, which is about a 20% premium above where DELL traded before there were rumors of a possible LBO. In recent days the stock has been bid up above $12.50, but that was caused by reckless rumors rather than any statements from DELL or its potential buyout partners. As for Barrons article and, or, what some shareowners may think is "fair value', these things mean nothing. DELL was down below $11 per share for quite awhile, and that trading price is the best measure of true "fair value".

What a silly comment. Dell traded at $30 for a long time also, maybe thats what it should be worth according to you. Stocks RARELY trade at their true value, no money for the house. The value of anything depends on what the buyer and seller agree on. My guess is MOST shareholders are not willing to give the farm away at your ridiculous price. This things will go for $16 or more.
